company.name: Bruno's, Inc.
company.business_description: Bruno's, Inc. uses information in consumer reports obtained from consumer reporting agencies in the consideration, acceptance, and denial of applicants for employment.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 615(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681m(a), and Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

complaint.factual_background: Bruno's, Inc., a corporation operating retail grocery stores, used consumer reports from consumer reporting agencies to make employment decisions. When the company denied job applications or rescinded employment offers based in whole or in part on information from consumer reports, it failed to notify applicants that consumer report information contributed to the adverse action and failed to provide the name and address of the consumer reporting agency that supplied the information, as required by the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

counts.title: Failure to Provide Adverse Action Notice
counts.representation: N/A - This case involves omissions rather than affirmative representations
counts.fact: Respondent denied applications or rescinded employment offers based in whole or in part on information supplied by a consumer reporting agency, but failed to advise consumers that the information contributed to the adverse action and failed to advise consumers of the name and address of the consumer reporting agency that supplied the information.
counts.conclusion: By and through the practices described in Paragraph Four, respondent has violated the provisions of Section 615(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681m(a), and has engaged in unfair and deceptive acts or practices in or affecting commerce in violation of Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act.

definitions.consumer: As defined in Section 603(c) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681a(c).
definitions.consumer report: As defined in Section 603(d) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681a(d).
definitions.consumer reporting agency: As defined in Section 603(f) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681a(f).

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Failing to Disclose Adverse Employment Actions Based on Consumer Reports
provisions.summary: Respondent must cease and desist from failing to disclose to employment applicants when adverse employment actions are based on consumer report information, including disclosing that the action was based on the report and providing the name and address of the consumer reporting agency.

requirements.description: Must disclose to applicants when employment is denied wholly or partly due to consumer report information, including that the adverse action was based on such report and the name and address of the consumer reporting agency
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS ORDERED that respondent Bruno's, Inc., a corporation, its successors and assigns, and its officers, agents, representatives, and employees, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, or other device, in connection with any application for employment, do forthwith cease and desist from failing, whenever employment is denied either wholly or partly because of information contained in a consumer report from a consumer reporting agency, to disclose to the applicant for employment at the time such adverse action is communicated to the applicant (a) that the adverse action was based wholly or partly on information contained in such a report and (b) the name and address of the consumer reporting agency making the report.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping Requirements
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain for at least five years documents demonstrating compliance with Part I, including employment evaluation criteria, employee instructions, notices to applicants, and complete application files for applicants for whom consumer reports were obtained and employment offers were not made or were withdrawn based on consumer report information.

requirements.description: Maintain and make available to FTC for five years documents demonstrating compliance, including employment evaluation criteria, employee instructions, notices to applicants, and application files
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent, and its successors and assigns, shall for at least five (5) years from the date of issuance of this Order, maintain and upon request make available to the Federal Trade Commission for inspection and copying, documents demonstrating compliance with the requirements of Part I of this Order, such documents to include, but not be limited to, all employment evaluation criteria relating to consumer reports, instructions given to employees regarding compliance with the provisions of this Order, all written notices or a written or electronically stored notation of the description of the form of notice and date such notice was provided to applicants pursuant to any provisions of this Order, and the complete application files for all applicants for whom consumer reports were obtained for whom offers of employment are not made or have been withheld, withdrawn, or rescinded based, in whole or in part, on information contained in a consumer report.

provisions.title: Order Distribution and Acknowledgment
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this Order at least once per year for five years to all persons responsible for compliance with Section 615(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

requirements.description: Deliver a copy of this Order at least once per year for five years to all persons responsible for compliance with Section 615(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent shall deliver a copy of this Order at least once per year for a period of five (5) years from the date of issuance of this Order, to all persons responsible for the respondent's compliance with Section 615(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any proposed corporate structure changes that may affect compliance obligations.

requirements.description: Notify FTC at least 30 days prior to any proposed corporate structure changes such as dissolution, assignment, sale, creation or dissolution of subsidiaries, or other changes affecting compliance obligations
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent shall notify the Federal Trade Commission at least thirty (30) days prior to any proposed change in the corporate structure of respondent such as dissolution, assignment, or sale resulting in the emergence of a successor operation, the creation or dissolution of subsidiaries or divisions, or any other change in the corporation which may affect compliance obligations arising out of the Order.

provisions.title: Initial Compliance Report
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a written compliance report with the FTC within 60 days of service of this Order.

requirements.description: File with the FTC a written report detailing compliance with this Order
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent shall, within sixty (60) days of service of this Order, file with the Federal Trade Commission a report, in writing, setting forth in detail the manner and form in which it has complied with this Order.

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This Order will terminate on July 29, 2017, or 20 years from the most recent date that the United States or FTC files a complaint in federal court alleging any violation of the Order, whichever comes later, with specific provisions for earlier termination and exceptions.

requirements.description: Order terminates on July 29, 2017, or 20 years from most recent complaint filing date, whichever is later
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that this Order will terminate on July 29, 2017, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Federal Trade Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying consent decree) in federal court alleging any violation of the Order, whichever comes later; provided, however, that the filing of such a complaint will not affect the duration of: A. Any paragraph in this Order that terminates in less than twenty (20) years; B. This Order's application to any respondent that is not named as a defendant in such complaint; and C. This Order if such complaint is filed after the Order has terminated pursuant to this paragraph.

duration.termination_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that this Order will terminate on July 29, 2017, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Federal Trade Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying consent decree) in federal court alleging any violation of the Order, whichever comes later; provided, however, that the filing of such a complaint will not affect the duration of: A. Any paragraph in this Order that terminates in less than twenty (20) years; B. This Order's application to any respondent that is not named as a defendant in such complaint; and C. This Order if such complaint is filed after the Order has terminated pursuant to this paragraph. Provided further, that if such complaint is dismissed or a federal court rules that the respondent did not violate any provision of the Order, and the dismissal or ruling is either not appealed or upheld on appeal, then the Order will terminate according to this paragraph as though the complaint was never filed, except that the Order will not terminate between the date such complaint is filed and the later of the deadline for appealing such dismissal or ruling and the date such dismissal or ruling is upheld on appeal.
